name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: RT @PlasticOceans: How could this be the 'end of Plastic'? Plant-based plastics or not, chemically these are STILL PLASTICS. In the ocean i‚Ä¶
retweet_text: How could this be the 'end of Plastic'? Plant-based plastics or not, chemically these are STILL PLASTICS. In the ocean it's all #plasticpollution. Let's wash away these empty claims and get some definitions straight... (1/12) https://t.co/tVteJkmBVy

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
"It is a sobering reminder that the issue of marine debris does not respect boundaries that we draw on maps"

James Beard on his expedition to Henderson Island; one of the most remote, yet densely polluted beaches on the planet.

You can read it here: https://t.co/hlz0u0dILr

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: When it comes to magic solutions to #plasticpollution ‚Äì and especially if they justify continued production of single-use plastic ‚Äì if it seems too good to be true, it probably is. #unBIOlievable (12/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: If it‚Äôs compostable, that raises questions about how effective a feedstock it would be for recyclers. If it‚Äôs touted as biodegradeable, they‚Äôre anticipating pollution as a likely end of life scenario for these single-use plastics. Why is that acceptable? (11/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: The message is confusing, suggesting 3 different, incompatible end of life scenarios. They say it can be composted, left to biodegrade, but ideally recycled. How as a consumer are you supposed to decipher that?  (10/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: 3. Marketing novel types of plastic for their ability to supposedly biodegrade in the environment incentivises easy 'throw-away' behaviour. This all distracts from the ultimate goal of establishing a closed-loop circular plastics economy. (9/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: This is why the UN have concluded biodegrable plastics are NOT a solution to ocean plastic pollution. https://t.co/UYjBZZnR5O (8/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: There are NO internationally recognised tests for marine biodegradability of plastics using realistic environtmental conditions. It is currently IMPOSSIBLE to back up these natural-environment biodegradeability claims. (7/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: Whether something can biodegrade in a landfill is different to biodegradability in a heated industrial composter, which is COMPLETELY different from the ability to biodegrade in the cold, dark conditions at the bottom of the ocean. (6/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: 2. ‚ÄòBIODEGRADEABILITY‚Äô: This is about the end of life of a plastic‚Äôs lifecycle. To make a plastic that‚Äôs ‚Äòbiodegradeable‚Äô means you‚Äôve got to able to test and prove its biodegradability in SPECIFIC conditions. (5/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: BUT it doesn‚Äôt make any difference when it comes to the rest of that plastic‚Äôs lifecycle. Bio-based plastics are JUST AS LIKELY to end as ocean #plasticpollution (4/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: Using plants instead of oil could be useful for moving away from fossil fuels at the plastic production stage... (3/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: 1. BIO-BASED PLASTICS: Making a plastic bottle out of plants means creating a bio-based plastic. The only difference between bio-based and conventional plastics is what they're made from. It is still a plastic. (2/12)

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: How could this be the 'end of Plastic'? Plant-based plastics or not, chemically these are STILL PLASTICS. In the ocean it's all #plasticpollution. Let's wash away these empty claims and get some definitions straight... (1/12) https://t.co/tVteJkmBVy

text: @EcoWatch Thank you for sharing, it is so important that people know where their plastic ends up!

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: üê¢ So, next time you buy a plastic item, make sure you consider its destiny. Can it be Reused? Reduced? Repurposed? Will it be effectively disposed of? Or will the bag used to put food on your table, inevitably become the turtle's not so tasty treat? https://t.co/yQA3dArjVl

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: Yet, a recent study found that 100% of the sampled turtles in the Mediterranean had macroplastic in their gastrointestinal tracts (Duncan et al., 2019a, b). This is due to floating plastic resembling their diets. In fact, all seven species are shown to ingest #plasticpollution https://t.co/Xg5VSkdkPE

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: @christophharris @MWhalan @suez Indeed. I think the general consensus in the room was to entirely remove unnecessary plastics from the supply chain. Remaining necessary plastic then must be captured and processed to recover the material, instead of leaked into the environment, landfilled or incinerated.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
A caveat of compostables being used for food contaminated cutlery, boxes, plates, coffee cups is that they rarely get put in a compostables ways stream. Especially if these items are used on-the-go.

@WRAP_UK @MarcusGover pushed for reusables to be the priority in these instances

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
Paul @BiomePlastics got a question about how to tackle customer confusion.

Diversification of materials in the hands of the consumer complicates how they dispose of them.

His group have produced educational videos to attempt to demystify bioplastics.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
General agreement: compostables present a good alternative for materials contaminated by food.

The UK has over 150 facilities to process compostables like food waste. Paul Mines from Biome Technologies argues this is sufficient to deal with an influx of compostable packaging

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
- petroleum based plastic is both non-renewable and heavily polluted. But they do store carbon, unlike compostables, which release carbon dioxide.
- biodegrable plastics don't degrade in the environment, still presenting issues for pollution

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
- reduction of virgin plastic (using petroleum) can be helped by bio-based (plant) plastic which is chemically very similar
- biodegrable plastics are not part of a closed loop economy (where the original material goes back into the system). This means more resources are needed.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
#WEETFEvents
Next up: discussion around bioplastics. 

But only very brief summary points because there was a lot of debate around this topic area! Does anyone following have specific points/questions about compostables or bioplastics? üôÇ

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
Encouraging food recycling will reduce contamination. This and kerbside sorting will improve the quality of recyclable waste.

Accessibility issues were mentioned with regard to barriers to correct home waste management: disabled, elderly, underpriviliged folk need to be included

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
Food contamination is an issue for both general and recycling bins,
1/4 general waste bin being food waste at time of audit.

"Bin brother" as it's been dubbed: food waste microchips track the use of food waste bins.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
#WEETFEvents 
Interesting case study about reform of waste management in Denighshire:

Not enough capacity in recycling bins, leading to recyclable material ending up in the general waste bin

"Bin snooper" audits found 1/2 of rubbish in the general waste bin was recyclable.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
Global trade of recyclable material is a core aspect of the UK's waste problem and we should seek to improve the quality of our exported materials in order to optimise the process.

The producer responsibility should extend to overseas facilities and Dr Read covered this well.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
Dr Read @suez and @WRAP_UK CEO Marcus Gover both touched on the importance of export in our waste management system.

Previously gaining a lot of flack in the media, Dr Read explains the mechanisms by which thorough testing and monitoring of overseas recycling facilities.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: "Capture material, remove unnecessary material, ban the worst, and tax the next worst"

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
Paraphrasing Dr Adam Read from @suez 

We shouldn't demonise plastic or packaging that serves a very real and important purpose in modern life.

But we need to collectively address leakage into the environment, underfunded collection systems, litter, and consumer behaviour.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: Paula points out that reduction of plastic altogether and leakage into the environment should be the top priority. Not exchanging plastic for another (less sustainable) material.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
Another general agreement is that plastic is so versatile and cheap that "plastiphobia" might be counterproductive.

This visible waste has caused outrage, and rightly so.

Leakage of plastic into the environment is the main problem, not the plastic itself.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
What these discussions are showing is that there are still a lot of unknowns about what the best solution is.

The unanimous consensus is that plastic production must be reduced overall.

Either through banning of unnecessary plastic, intelligent design, or consumer behaviour.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
#WEETFEvents
Topics covered in panel discussion:
- Balance between plastic use and food waste
- Health concerns about recycled plastic
- Low plastic recovery rates in UK affecting goals to increase recycled content in packaging
- Design solutions to achieve sustainability goals

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
@wwf_uk Sustainable materials specialist Paula Chin delivered a passionate speech on plastiphobia why recycling won't fix everything

She points out some false solutions such as the UK plastic bag charge. This resulted in an increase in tonnage of plastic use bc of bags for life

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
Some excellent sentiments by Prof Malcolm:

Laws are focussed on a linear plastic economy. We need to mend the gap between production and consumption of plastic. 

Waste should be seen as a resource by producers and consumers.

name: Plastic Oceans UK
text:
So far, we've heard about how to regulate a circular plastic economy through law making by Prof Rosalind Malcolm @UniOfSurrey

A strong theme coming through being the focus on science-based approaches and improving the value of waste at the end of its life.
#WEETFEvents

text: @bglemas @plasticoceansuk Absolutely Bernadette! We strongly support Producer Responsibility as a regulatory response and 'enhancing' and 'improving' the regime to focus on lesser quantities, and bringing more businesses into the regime. name: Plastic Oceans UK
text: @lizbonnin Hi Liz - all plastic degradation is an estimate - its only been around for 100 years so no-one knows and lab tests can't replicate environmental conditions.  We usually say it will 'persist', so to be consistent with the notation used for chemical degradation (Geoff Brighty POUK)
